data.title: Platinum Equity's Fund II: Too Fast, Too Furious?
data.meta_description: Explore millions of resources from scholarly journals, books, newspapers, videos and more, on the ProQuest Platform.
data.text:
Turnaround firm Platinum Equity LLC has done some things that give its investors pause lately. Even as other private equity firms' media investments crashed and burned, it struck its first deal in the newspaper industry in March, buying the San Diego Union-Tribune. As it goes about slashing costs there, it appears interested in other media properties, including BusinessWeek and the Boston Globe. It's also spent more than two years, and considerable money, courting bankrupt auto parts maker Delphi Corp., ultimately losing the company to lenders and General Motors Co. in July. Along the way, the firm took some hits to its reputation for a perceived sweetheart deal with the U.S. government and ran into a colorful judge who dismissed Platinum as just "guys in suits" before adding insult to injury by denying a claim for reimbursement of up to $30 million in expenses related to the deal.

Perhaps most importantly, at a time when many limited partners fear their turnaround managers invested too much, too soon, Platinum Equity Capital Partners II LP, which closed at $2.75 billion in September 2008, is some 50% called down already. "When a recession hits, the first thing you've got to do is duck and I'm afraid Platinum didn't duck," said one LP. But Platinum staunchly defends its recent course. Principal Mark Barnhill said the firm has remained disciplined on price. "We specialize in businesses facing complex operational challenges in declining or transitioning markets," he said. "You're not going to find us chasing high-flying companies in high-flying markets. You'll find us looking at specific opportunities in those markets where our operational skills can create the most value."
